The probability density that the momentum assumes a value in the vicinity of $p$ is, then, given by  

$$
P(p)=\frac{2\pi^{\frac{1}{2}}\delta}{h}\exp\Big\{-\,\left(\frac{2\pi}{h}\right)^{2}\,\delta^{2}(p\!-\!p^{0})^{2}\Big\},
$$  

which implies that the values of $p$ are essentially within the domain of width $h/2\pi\delta$ around $p^{0}$.  

The probability density of the coordinate $q$ for $\psi$ of Eq. (59.12), by the way, is given by  

$$
P(q)=\frac{1}{\bar{\pi}^{\frac{1}{2}}\delta}\exp\Big\{-\frac{1}{\delta^{2}}\,(q\!-\!q^{0})^{2}\Big\}.
$$  

(iv) The Uncertainty Relation  

The two uncertainties $(\varDelta q$ and $\varDelta p)$ obtained in the last subsection seem to show a reciprocal relation. Namely, according to Eqs. (59.14) and (59.17), respectively,  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{\varDelta q=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\,\delta}}\\ {{\varDelta p=\left(\frac{h}{2\pi}\right)\frac{1}{\delta\sqrt{2}}\,.}}\end{array}
$$  

That is, $\varDelta q$ is proportional to $\delta$ while $\varDelta p$ is to $1/\delta$. Therefore, an effort to reduce $\varDelta q$ inevitably causes an increase in $\varDelta p$ and vice versa.  

From Eq. (59.20) we find that  

$$
\varDelta p\cdot\varDelta q={\textstyle{\frac{1}{2}}}{\frac{h}{2\pi}}\,.
$$  

It says, for instance, that $\varDelta\phi$ approaches infinity if $\varDelta q$ tends to 0, and $\varDelta q$ approaches infinity if $\varDelta p$ tends to 0. In other words, in a state in which the coordinate has a definite value, the value of momentum is completely indefinite, and in a state in which the momentum has a definite value, the value of coordinate is completely indefinite.  

The relation (59.21) has been derived from the consideration of a specific wave packet of the form of Eq. (59.12). The question is then, what happens if we take a state other than that chosen here?
